attributes.name: [Implementation Services] Synthetics API and Browser Test Config Check

definition.text:
# Synthetics Config Check

- [ ] Tag your tests
- [ ] Notifications are configured to send the right data to right team
- [ ] (Optional) Create private location(s)
- [ ] Use snippets to pre-fill sections of test based on common configurations
- [ ] Use variables where applicable
- [ ] Connect data and traces
- [ ] Connect synthetic and rum data
- [ ] Connect synthetics and SLOs
- [ ] Create reusable browser test journeys across test suite
- [ ] Use authentication in tests
- [ ] (Optional) Use custom JavaScript assertions in browser tests
- [ ] Manage test ownership and permissions
- [ ] Review the test results
- [ ] Understand what synthetic monitoring metrics are available
- [ ] Review the OOTB Synthetic dashboards

## Tag your tests

**Status:** Not Started

Monitor tags add dimensions to your monitors, allowing you to filter, aggregate, and visualize them just like any other kind of monitoring data (i.e., metrics, logs, and traces) in Datadog.

**Recommendation:** In Step 2: Define Request of your test, add the relevant tags to the "Environment", "Team," and "Additional Tags" section. More info can be found in the [Best Practices for Tagging Your Monitors ](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/tagging-best-practices-monitors/)blog post.

## Notifications are configured to send the right data to right team

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** Step 7: Monitor in the test creation page uses. the same notification message process used in Datadog monitors. Tailor the monitor section using variables and conditional statements. Integrate synthetic tests monitor with Statuspage, if applicable. More details [here](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/synthetic-test-monitors/).

## (Optional) Create private location(s)

**Status:** Not Started

Private locations allow you to monitor internal-facing applications or private URLs that aren’t accessible from the public internet. They are Docker containers or Windows services that you can install anywhere inside your private network.

**Recommendation:** Create private locations following directions in [this page](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/platform/private_locations/?tab=docker) if you need to:
- monitor internal facing apps or private URLs
-   Verify the application performance in your internal testing environment before you release new features to production with [Synthetic tests in your CI/CD pipelines](https://docs.datadoghq.com/continuous_testing/cicd_integrations).
-   Compare the application performance from inside and outside your internal network.

## Use snippets to pre-fill sections of test based on common configurations

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** When setting up a new Synthetic Monitoring API test, use snippets to automatically fill in basic auth, performance, and regions, rather than selecting these options manually. The following snippets are available: basic auth, performance, and regions. See [here](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/api_tests/http_tests/?tab=requestoptions#snippets) for more details.

## Use variables where applicable

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** Create [local variables](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/api_tests/http_tests/?tab=requestoptions#create-local-variables) for unique test cases. Create [global variables](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/api_tests/http_tests/?tab=requestoptions#use-variables) for common patterns that will be reused across tests (ie. authorization). For global variables storing sensitive data, [hide and obfuscate variable value](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/browser_tests/app-that-requires-login/#account-security:~:text=Hide%20and%20obfuscate%20variable%20value%20to%20hide%20their%20values%20from%20test%20results.) to hide their values from test results.

## Connect data and traces

**Status:** Not Started

Note: Be aware of the supported libraries list [here](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/platform/apm/?tab=datadog#supported-libraries).

**Recommendation:** For your [HTTP API tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/api_tests/http_tests/?tab=requestoptions), [Multistep API tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/multistep?tab=requestoptions), and [browser tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/browser_tests/) for APM, create a test that hits your traced HTTP server, and Datadog automatically links the trace generated by your server to the corresponding test result. 

To link browser test results, allow the URLs you want the APM integration headers added to. You can do this in [Synthetic Settings](https://app.datadoghq.com/synthetics/settings/integrations). Use `*` for wildcards:

```text
https://*.datadoghq.com/*
```

## Connect synthetic and RUM data

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** You can create Synthetic browser tests from your session replays in RUM to track performance based on real user behavior. Use [this guide](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/explore-rum-through-synthetics/) to configure.

## Connect Synthetics and SLOS

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** Maintaining service level agreements with external or internal customers often requires measuring uptime percentage. Calculate this uptime percentage with Synthetic API tests and configure an SLO widget. See [this guide](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/uptime-percentage-widget/) for more details.

## Create reusable browser test journeys across test suite

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** Create subtests for common workflows such as: login steps, application functionalities across envs, cleaning up test environment after tests in which db objects are created. See [this page](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/reusing-browser-test-journeys/) for process.

## Use authentication in tests

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** If your endpoint requires authentication, you can add your credentials when creating a test inside the steps. See the guides below for the particular test type you are setting up:
- [Use Authentication In API And Multistep API Tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/authentication-protocols/?tab=basicaccess)
- [Monitor An Application That Requires Authentication With Browser Testing](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/browser_tests/app-that-requires-login/)
- [Use Time-based One-time Passwords (TOTPs) For Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) In Browser Tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/browser-tests-totp/)
- [Use Passkeys (FIDO2) In Browser Tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/browser-tests-passkeys/)
- Bonus: [Use Email Validation In Browser Tests](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/email-validation/)

## (Optional) Use custom JavaScript assertions in browser tests

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** For more advanced use cases, leverage custom JavaScript [<https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/explore-rum-through-synthetics/>](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/custom-javascript-assertion/)

## Manage test ownership and permissions

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** By default, only users with the [Datadog Admin and Datadog Standard roles](https://docs.datadoghq.com/account_management/rbac/?tab=datadogapplication#datadog-default-roles) can access the Synthetic Monitoring **Default Settings** page. Where applicable, edit the access of the synthetic tests in Step 8: Permissions. This is critical for Synthetic tests related to SLOs that should not be updated without prior authorization. See documentation [here](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/platform/settings/?tab=specifyvalue#permissions).

## Review the test results

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** Use the guides below to better understand how to navigate the test result page:
- [Browser Testing Results](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/browser_tests/test_results)
- [Understand How Synthetic Test Retries Determine Monitor Status](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/synthetic-test-retries-monitor-status/)
- [Mobile App Testing Results](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/mobile_app_testing/mobile_app_tests/results?tab=ios)

## Understand what synthetic monitoring metrics are available

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** Review the [metrics documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/platform/metrics/) to understand what Synthetics metrics are available for use in visualizations/monitors.

## Review the OOTB Synthetic dashboards

**Status:** Not Started

**Recommendation:** View the OOTB Synthetic dashboards to better understand your test performance.
- [Synthetics - API Test Performance](/dash/integration/30695/synthetics---api-test-performance?fromUser=false&refresh_mode=sliding&from_ts=1738702368812&to_ts=1738705968812&live=true)

# Manage your Synthetic Tests Programmatically

## API
Datadog recommends creating your browser tests in the Datadog UI first and retrieving your tests configurations with the API. 

Use these resources for enablement:
- [Create An API Test With The API](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/create-api-test-with-the-api/)
- [Manage your browser tests with the API](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/manage-browser-tests-through-the-api/#manage-your-browser-tests-with-the-api)

## Terraform
You can use the [Datadog Terraform provider](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/DataDog/datadog/latest/docs) to create and manage browser tests and associated synthetics resources programmatically through a Terraform configuration. You can also [import](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/cli/import) your existing resources into your Terraform configuration, or reference existing resources as external [data sources](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/data-sources).

See [this guide](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/manage-browser-tests-through-the-api/#manage-your-browser-tests-with-terraform) for more details.

# Synthetics 101

Four main categories of test:
1. API Test
2. Multi-Step API Test
3. Browser Test
4. Mobile Application Test

## Understand How Synthetic Test Retries Determine Monitor Status
([Source](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/synthetic-test-retries-monitor-status/))

Two layers of evaluation:

Group Evaluation | Description
------|------
 **Local** | Evaluation of the location status. Fast retry results are used in this evaluation.
 **Total** | Evaluation of the test status.

To reduce alert fatigue, Synthetic tests can be retried when a test run fails. If you have configured a test to be retried on failures, this is a **fast retry**.

While fast retry results are used in the local group evaluation, only the final retry is taken into account in the total group evaluation. The original run and all intermediate retries are discarded from the evaluation. A run that is still failing after it has reached the maximum number of retries is considered final, and this final result is taken into account in the total group evaluation.

See ["Retries that overlap with other test runs"](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/guide/synthetic-test-retries-monitor-status/#retries-that-overlap-with-other-test-runs) for visualizations that illustrate local vs. group evaluation for retries.
